history.event: SUNDAY, JUNE 14, 1942 , I'll begin from the moment I got you, the moment I saw you lying on the table among my other birthday presents.

To enhance the image of this long-awaited friend in my imagination, I don't want to jot down the facts in this diary the way most people would do, but I want the diary to be my friend, and I'm going to call this friend Kitty.
Since no one would understand a word of my stories to Kitty if I were to plunge right in, I'd better provide a brief sketch of my life, much as I dislike doing so.
SATURDAY, JUNE 20, 1942 , Dearest Kitty!
SUNDAY, JUNE 21, 1942 , Dearest Kitty, Our entire class is quaking in its boots.
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 24, 1942 , Dearest Kitty, It's sweltering.
WEDNESDAY, JULY 1, 1942 , Dearest Kitty, Until today I honestly couldn't find the time to write you.
Now my grandmother wants me to see Ursul and not you, but I don't agree and I'm not going to.
SUNDAY, JULY 5, 1942 , Dear Kitty,  The graduation ceremony in the Jewish Theater on Friday went as expected.
WEDNESDAY, JULY 8, 1942 ,  Dearest Kitty, It seems like years since Sunday morning.
But as you can see, Kitty, I'm still alive, and that's the main thing, Father says.

FRIDAY, JULY 10, 1942 , Dearest Kitty, I've probably bored you with my long description of our house, but I still think you should know where I've ended up; how I ended up here is  something you'll figure out from my next letters.
SATURDAY, JULY 11, 1942 , Dearest Kitty, Father, Mother and Margot still can't get used to the chiming of the Westertoren clock, which tells us the time every quarter of an hour.

Moortje.last_event: Moortje is so sweet, and I love her so much that I keep dreaming she'll come back to us.

history.event: When I couldn't wait any longer, I went to the dining room, where Moortje (the cat) welcomed me by rubbing against my legs.
At seven-thirty we too closed the door behind us; Moortje, my cat, was the only living creature I said good-bye to.
And sometimes they talk about Moortje and I can't take that at all.
Moortje is my weak spot.
Moortje is so sweet, and I love her so much that I keep dreaming she'll come back to us.

Otto Frank.last_event: Daddy's always so nice.

history.event: A little after seven I went to Daddy and Mama and then to the living room to open my presents, and you were the first thing I saw, maybe one of my nicest presents.

From Daddy and Mama I got a blue blouse, a game, a bottle of grape juice, which to my mind tastes a bit like wine (after all, wine is made from grapes), a puzzle, a jar of cold cream, 2.50 guilders and a gift certificate for two books.
My father, the most adorable father I've ever seen, didn't marry my mother until he was thirty-six and she was twenty-five.
Because we're Jewish, my father immigrated to Holland in 1933, when he became the Managing Director of the Dutch Opekta Company, which manufactures products used in making jam.
Father and Mother are out and Margot has gone to play Ping-Pong with some other young people at her friend Trees's.

If it gets so bad that they start rambling on about "asking Father's permission," I swerve slightly on my bike, my schoolbag falls, and the young man feels obliged to get off his bike and hand me the bag, by which time I've switched the conversation to another topic.
It was about a mother duck and a father swan with three baby ducklings who were bitten to death by the father because they quacked too much.
My bike was stolen during Easter vacation, and Father gave Mother's bike to some Christian friends for safekeeping.
Monday evening Hello came over to meet Father and Mother.
Father was furious.
Father has been home a lot lately.
A few days ago, as we were taking a stroll around our neighborhood square, Father began to talk about going into hiding.
But when, Father?
But as you can see, Kitty, I'm still alive, and that's the main thing, Father says.
Father has received a call-up notice from the SS, she whispered.
How could we let Father go to such a fate?
The thought of Father off visiting someone in the Jewish Hospital and completely unaware of what was happening, the long wait for Mother, the heat, the suspense -- all this reduced us to silence.
Every time the bell rang, either Margot or I had to tiptoe downstairs to see if it was Father, and we didn't let anyone else in.
When she and I were sitting in our bedroom, Margot told me that the call-up was not for Father, but for her.
But thank goodness she won't be going; Mother had said so herself, which must be what Father had meant when he talked to me about our going into hiding.
Father finally came home around five o'clock, and we called Mr. Kleiman to ask if he could come by that evening.
Miep, who's worked for Father's company since 1933, has become a close friend, and so has her husband Jan.

THURSDAY, JULY 9, 1942 , Dearest Kitty, So there we were, Father, Mother and I, walking in the pouring rain, each of us with a schoolbag and a shopping bag filled to the brim with the most varied assortment of items.
Only when we were walking down the street did Father and Mother reveal, little by little, what the plan was.
The hiding place was located in Father's office building.
Father didn't have a lot of people working in his office, just Mr. Kugler, Mr. Kleiman, Miep and a twenty-three-year-old typist named Bep Voskuijl, all of whom were informed of our coming.
But Father and I, the two cleaner-uppers in the family, started in right away.
We hadn't eaten a hot meal all day, but we didn't care; Mother and Margot were too tired and keyed up to eat, and Father and I were too busy.
Bep and Miep went grocery shopping with our ration coupons, Father worked on our blackout screens, we scrubbed the kitchen floor, and were once again busy from sunup to sundown.
SATURDAY, JULY 11, 1942 , Dearest Kitty, Father, Mother and Margot still can't get used to the chiming of the Westertoren clock, which tells us the time every quarter of an hour.
Thanks to Father -- who brought my entire postcard and movie-star collection here beforehand -- and to a brush and a pot of glue, I was able to plaster the walls with pictures.
I was so scared someone might hear it that I literally begged Father to take me back upstairs.

Actually, you can hardly call them that, since they're nothing but scraps of fabric, varying greatly in shape, quality and pattern, which Father and I stitched crookedly together with unskilled fingers.
Daddy's the only one who understands me, now and again, though he usually sides with Mother and Margot.
Daddy's always so nice.

history.event: SATURDAY, JUNE 20,1942 Writing in a diary is a really strange experience for someone like me.

Yes, paper does have more patience, and since I'm not planning to let anyone else read this stiff-backed notebook grandly referred to as a "diary," unless I should ever find a real friend, it probably won't make a bit of difference.
Now I'm back to the point that prompted me to keep a diary in the first place: I don't have a friend.
This is why I've started the diary.

To enhance the image of this long-awaited friend in my imagination, I don't want to jot down the facts in this diary the way most people would do, but I want the diary to be my friend, and I'm going to call this friend Kitty.
The first thing I stuck in was this diary, and then curlers, handkerchiefs, schoolbooks, a comb and some old letters.

Because we're Jewish, my father immigrated to Holland in 1933, when he became the Managing Director of the Dutch Opekta Company, which manufactures products used in making jam.
My mother, Edith Hollander Frank, went with him to Holland in September, while Margot and I were sent to Aachen to stay with our grandmother.
Margot went to Holland in December, and I followed in February, when I was plunked down on the table as a birthday present for Margot.
In the summer of 1940 we didn't do much for my birthday either, since the fighting had just ended in Holland.

Jews.last_event: Only now do I realize how pleasant a streetcar is, but we Jews are no longer allowed to make use of this luxury; our own two feet are good enough for us.

history.event: Our freedom was severely restricted by a series of anti-Jewish decrees: Jews were required to wear a yellow star; Jews were required to turn in their bicycles; Jews were forbidden to use street-cars; Jews were forbidden to ride in cars, even their own; Jews were required to do their shopping between 3 and 5 P.M.; Jews were required to frequent only Jewish-owned barbershops and beauty parlors; Jews were forbidden to be out on the streets between 8 P.M. and 6 A.M.; Jews were forbidden to attend theaters, movies or any other forms of entertainment; Jews were forbidden to use swimming pools, tennis courts, hockey fields or any other athletic fields; Jews were forbidden to go rowing; Jews were forbidden to take part in any athletic activity in public; Jews were forbidden to sit in their gardens or those of their friends after 8 P.M.; Jews were forbidden to visit Christians in their homes; Jews were required to attend Jewish schools, etc.
Only now do I realize how pleasant a streetcar is, but we Jews are no longer allowed to make use of this luxury; our own two feet are good enough for us.

Otto Frank.last_event: Daddy's the only one who understands me, now and again, though he usually sides with Mother and Margot.

history.event: A little after seven I went to Daddy and Mama and then to the living room to open my presents, and you were the first thing I saw, maybe one of my nicest presents.

From Daddy and Mama I got a blue blouse, a game, a bottle of grape juice, which to my mind tastes a bit like wine (after all, wine is made from grapes), a puzzle, a jar of cold cream, 2.50 guilders and a gift certificate for two books.
My father, the most adorable father I've ever seen, didn't marry my mother until he was thirty-six and she was twenty-five.
Father and Mother are out and Margot has gone to play Ping-Pong with some other young people at her friend Trees's.
Monday evening Hello came over to meet Father and Mother.
The thought of Father off visiting someone in the Jewish Hospital and completely unaware of what was happening, the long wait for Mother, the heat, the suspense -- all this reduced us to silence.
But thank goodness she won't be going; Mother had said so herself, which must be what Father had meant when he talked to me about our going into hiding.

THURSDAY, JULY 9, 1942 , Dearest Kitty, So there we were, Father, Mother and I, walking in the pouring rain, each of us with a schoolbag and a shopping bag filled to the brim with the most varied assortment of items.
Only when we were walking down the street did Father and Mother reveal, little by little, what the plan was.
We hadn't eaten a hot meal all day, but we didn't care; Mother and Margot were too tired and keyed up to eat, and Father and I were too busy.
SATURDAY, JULY 11, 1942 , Dearest Kitty, Father, Mother and Margot still can't get used to the chiming of the Westertoren clock, which tells us the time every quarter of an hour.
Daddy's the only one who understands me, now and again, though he usually sides with Mother and Margot.

My mother, Edith Hollander Frank, went with him to Holland in September, while Margot and I were sent to Aachen to stay with our grandmother.
Father and Mother are out and Margot has gone to play Ping-Pong with some other young people at her friend Trees's.

Margot and Mother have recovered somewhat.
SUNDAY, JULY 12, 1942 , They've all been so nice to me this last month because of my birthday, and yet every day I feel myself drifting further away from Mother and Margot.
Mother said, "Well, Margot, it's easy to see you're not used to working; otherwise, you'd have known better than to yank the plug out by the cord."

history.event: Father and Mother are out and Margot has gone to play Ping-Pong with some other young people at her friend Trees's.

We hadn't eaten a hot meal all day, but we didn't care; Mother and Margot were too tired and keyed up to eat, and Father and I were too busy.

hockey fields.last_event: Our freedom was severely restricted by a series of anti-Jewish decrees: Jews were required to wear a yellow star; Jews were required to turn in their bicycles; Jews were forbidden to use street-cars; Jews were forbidden to ride in cars, even their own; Jews were required to do their shopping between 3 and 5 P.M.; Jews were required to frequent only Jewish-owned barbershops and beauty parlors; Jews were forbidden to be out on the streets between 8 P.M. and 6 A.M.; Jews were forbidden to attend theaters, movies or any other forms of entertainment; Jews were forbidden to use swimming pools, tennis courts, hockey fields or any other athletic fields; Jews were forbidden to go rowing; Jews were forbidden to take part in any athletic activity in public; Jews were forbidden to sit in their gardens or those of their friends after 8 P.M.; Jews were forbidden to visit Christians in their homes; Jews were required to attend Jewish schools, etc.

diary.last_event: To enhance the image of this long-awaited friend in my imagination, I don't want to jot down the facts in this diary the way most people would do, but I want the diary to be my friend, and I'm going to call this friend Kitty.

history.event: A little after seven I went to Daddy and Mama and then to the living room to open my presents, and you were the first thing I saw, maybe one of my nicest presents.

From Daddy and Mama I got a blue blouse, a game, a bottle of grape juice, which to my mind tastes a bit like wine (after all, wine is made from grapes), a puzzle, a jar of cold cream, 2.50 guilders and a gift certificate for two books.
My father, the most adorable father I've ever seen, didn't marry my mother until he was thirty-six and she was twenty-five.
Father and Mother are out and Margot has gone to play Ping-Pong with some other young people at her friend Trees's.
Monday evening Hello came over to meet Father and Mother.
The thought of Father off visiting someone in the Jewish Hospital and completely unaware of what was happening, the long wait for Mother, the heat, the suspense -- all this reduced us to silence.
But thank goodness she won't be going; Mother had said so herself, which must be what Father had meant when he talked to me about our going into hiding.

THURSDAY, JULY 9, 1942 , Dearest Kitty, So there we were, Father, Mother and I, walking in the pouring rain, each of us with a schoolbag and a shopping bag filled to the brim with the most varied assortment of items.
Only when we were walking down the street did Father and Mother reveal, little by little, what the plan was.
We hadn't eaten a hot meal all day, but we didn't care; Mother and Margot were too tired and keyed up to eat, and Father and I were too busy.
SATURDAY, JULY 11, 1942 , Dearest Kitty, Father, Mother and Margot still can't get used to the chiming of the Westertoren clock, which tells us the time every quarter of an hour.
Daddy's the only one who understands me, now and again, though he usually sides with Mother and Margot.

Margot and Mother have recovered somewhat.
SUNDAY, JULY 12, 1942 , They've all been so nice to me this last month because of my birthday, and yet every day I feel myself drifting further away from Mother and Margot.
Mother said, "Well, Margot, it's easy to see you're not used to working; otherwise, you'd have known better than to yank the plug out by the cord."

the Dutch Opekta Company.last_event: Because we're Jewish, my father immigrated to Holland in 1933, when he became the Managing Director of the Dutch Opekta Company, which manufactures products used in making jam.

schoolbag.last_event: THURSDAY, JULY 9, 1942 , Dearest Kitty, So there we were, Father, Mother and I, walking in the pouring rain, each of us with a schoolbag and a shopping bag filled to the brim with the most varied assortment of items.

history.event: If it gets so bad that they start rambling on about "asking Father's permission," I swerve slightly on my bike, my schoolbag falls, and the young man feels obliged to get off his bike and hand me the bag, by which time I've switched the conversation to another topic.

heartbreaking farewell.last_event: At the end of the year we were both in tears as we said a heartbreaking farewell, because I'd been accepted at the Jewish Lyceum, where Margot also went to school.

Otto Frank.last_event: Daddy's the only one who understands me, now and again, though he usually sides with Mother and Margot.

history.event: Father and Mother are out and Margot has gone to play Ping-Pong with some other young people at her friend Trees's.
Every time the bell rang, either Margot or I had to tiptoe downstairs to see if it was Father, and we didn't let anyone else in.
When she and I were sitting in our bedroom, Margot told me that the call-up was not for Father, but for her.
We hadn't eaten a hot meal all day, but we didn't care; Mother and Margot were too tired and keyed up to eat, and Father and I were too busy.
SATURDAY, JULY 11, 1942 , Dearest Kitty, Father, Mother and Margot still can't get used to the chiming of the Westertoren clock, which tells us the time every quarter of an hour.

hockey fields.last_event: Our freedom was severely restricted by a series of anti-Jewish decrees: Jews were required to wear a yellow star; Jews were required to turn in their bicycles; Jews were forbidden to use street-cars; Jews were forbidden to ride in cars, even their own; Jews were required to do their shopping between 3 and 5 P.M.; Jews were required to frequent only Jewish-owned barbershops and beauty parlors; Jews were forbidden to be out on the streets between 8 P.M. and 6 A.M.; Jews were forbidden to attend theaters, movies or any other forms of entertainment; Jews were forbidden to use swimming pools, tennis courts, hockey fields or any other athletic fields; Jews were forbidden to go rowing; Jews were forbidden to take part in any athletic activity in public; Jews were forbidden to sit in their gardens or those of their friends after 8 P.M.; Jews were forbidden to visit Christians in their homes; Jews were required to attend Jewish schools, etc.
